And in New York state there are even more adventures—great paddling destinations from Long Island to the Adirondacks.
Camp out on isolated islands.

Last year, I rented a small house on Vega IV, a sea world, all islands and reefs and archipelagos, turquoise waters and aquamarine skies, sunrises like symphonies and sunsets like stars gone supernova.
In addition, in the braided-stream category, there are bar-braided and island-braided channels (islands are vegetated bars).
The business and financial center and the signature soaring architecture are on Hong Kong Island.
Hong Kong’s other, less developed islands, Lantau, Lamma, and Cheung Chau, provide getaways.
ELLIE SATTLER You lost as much as we did on that island, we shouldn't have deserted you.
Dr. Grant, I want to apologize to you for burdening you with the safety of what amounted to three children on two separate islands.
I had no intention of ever hurting anyone, but misfortune seemed to be the norm on the islands.
Before the disaster on Isla Nublar, I thought of myself as the creator of a perfect system, a god of the island itself.
I have long considered myself the steward of the islands and their inhabitants, but I will not be here forever.
JOHN HAMMOND (CONT'D) Before I leave you, I'd like to let you know I've done everything in my power to provide for the welfare and well being of the families of those souls lost on the islands.
I've also set up a trust fund for the defense of the islands, Mr. Perkins will be able to provide you with all the necessary paperwork, and I've retained him as chief counsel for you.
I have been on this island for two weeks, and I've seen no sign of either the T-Rex or the Spinosaurus.
It might as well be back on the island.
JEFFERY CLARK My name is Jeffery Clark; I've been hunting on an island off the coast, and I needed to re-supply.
I'm here now, and I'll be on my way back to the island just as soon as I buy some food.
What island were you hunting on?
JEFFERY CLARK They weren't on the island either.
ALAN GRANT Right, and one of them was killed by the Spinosaur while I was on the island.
There could be a thousand reasons you didn't see the T-Rexes on the island.
ELLIE SATTLER As it turns out, the spino was one of the first dinosaurs bred on the island.
We are the only people who can protect the animals and the island.

The story of the 509th is a tale of an elite outfit that lived in a bubble of secrecy and endured the taunts of other war-weary U.S. units that resented sharing a small Pacific island with the 509th, which appeared exempt from combat.
Tinian Island was the staging area where the 509th moved after its creation in the desert.
By spring, the 509th prepared to move to Tinian Island, near Guam and Saipan.
Tinian Island had been captured from Japan, and the Seabees, the construction arm of the Navy, had built two large airfields.
The 509th took North Field and stayed in relative isolation from other B-29 units on the island.
But dere's a island, just south of de straits, where I trade spice for...
Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: beach [Black Pearl seen stranded on a beach, through a spyglass] SHRIMPER: My brother will take you ashore.
Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: throne [cannibal drums are pounding] JACK SPARROW: No/Oup!

Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: cages [the men begin swinging the cages with increasingly wide arcs] [both cages finally come within reach of the cliff, they grab vines and hang on to the cliff] GIBBS: Put your legs through, start to climb!
CANNIBAL ISLAND: throne [drums pounding, a cannibal crosses a bridge to the bonfire area] Ahhh!

Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: hut [Jack is running off with the bamboo pole tied to his back] [Jack encounters the cannibal boy, standing silently with a fork and a knife, one in each hand] [Jack grabs the knife from the boy, and begins cutting his rope off] [two cannibal women appear] [Jack charges, but the bamboo pole on his back spears a coconut in a pile near the cliff edge] [Jack turns suddenly, which flings the coconut off the end of the pole into a cannibal's face] [the cannibal slowly lifts the dripping coconut off his face, scowling at Jack] Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: cage [the cage rolls over a ledge into a small chasm holding a river] [cannibals throw spears and shoot arrows at the men in the water, the men swim underwater] GIBBS: This way, lads!

Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: hut [Jack is running off with the bamboo pole tied to his back] [Jack encounters the cannibal boy, standing silently with a fork and a knife, one in each hand] [Jack grabs the knife from the boy, and begins cutting his rope off] [two cannibal women appear] [Jack charges, but the bamboo pole on his back spears a coconut in a pile near the cliff edge] [Jack turns suddenly, which flings the coconut off the end of the pole into a cannibal's face] [the cannibal slowly lifts the dripping coconut off his face, scowling at Jack] Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: cage [the cage rolls over a ledge into a small chasm holding a river] [cannibals throw spears and shoot arrows at the men in the water, the men swim underwater] GIBBS: This way, lads!

Scene: CANNIBAL ISLAND: Jack [the two cannibal women throw numerous fruits at Jack while the pole is still on his back] [several of the fruits become impaled along the pole, making Jack look like he's part of a shish-ka-bob] CANNIBAL BOY: Da litozo!
MERCER: Most recently seen on the island of Tortuga, then left, in the company of a known pirate, Jack Sparrow.
The Palmedo House, built in 1988, reinterprets the American Colonial architecture of its location—Long Island.

Although the multi-paned windows are present at an upper level of the wall, the corner of the room is glazed with large, mullionless sheets of plate glass, offering dramatic views of Long Island Sound.
He obliged them in a string of high-profile commissions: magnificent mansions along Fifth Avenue, country houses on Long Island, and palatial “cottages” in Newport, Rhode Island.
He obliged them in a string of high-profile commissions: magnificent mansions along Fifth Avenue, country houses on Long Island, and palatial “cottages” in Newport, Rhode Island.
Short walk to sandwich island.

Major shopping areas are Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon, especially along Nathan Road; Central on Hong Kong Island, particularly for upscale designer goods; Causeway Bay for slightly better prices; and the Hollywood Road area.
Bars with views and live music include Sky Lounge in the Sheraton Hotel and Towers, Tsim Sha Tsui; and Cyrano in the Island Shangri-La in Pacific Place.
On Hong Kong Island, Repulse Bay is the most popular; others are Shek O on the east coast and Stanley and Deep Water Bay on the south coast.
On the outlying islands, Cheung Chau and Cheung Sha are on Lantau, and Hung Shing Ye and Lo So Shing on Lamma; inquire about water pollution levels.
The Discovery Bay Golf Club on Lantau island (Tel. 2987 7273) has an 18-hole Robert Trent Jones Jr. course, open to visitors Monday, Tuesday, and Friday.
The Lantau Trail is a 69-km (43-mile) circular trail on Lantau Island that begins and ends at Silvermine Bay.
The racing schedule is September to June, and Hong Kong maintains two tracks — the older Happy Valley course on Hong Kong Island and the striking Sha Tin track in the New Territories.
For children who love boats, riding the Star Ferry or ferry trips to outlying islands will be exciting, and the Dolphin Watch trip (see page 113) is certain to appeal.

T he crowded Kowloon peninsula and the booming New Territories on the mainland call for some serious sightseeing; but we begin across Victoria Harbor on Hong Kong Island, where the city was first founded and which remains the center of government, business, and commerce.
The big green-and-white boat weaves its way through an ever-changing obstacle course of both large and small craft, and the soaring skyline of Hong Kong Island draws nearer.
Farther west is the ferry terminal for the outlying islands.
You can walk around the peak for impressive views of Hong Kong, the coastline, and the islands in 45 minutes on Lugard and Harlech roads.
The Western District is one of Hong Kong’s oldest neighborhoods, and its narrow streets hold a collection of fascinating traditional shops and enterprises.
Walk west along Hollywood Road until you come to Man Mo Temple, the island’s oldest house of worship (though the date of its founding is subject to dispute).

Aberdeen, the island’s oldest settlement, once a pirate lair, is home to the “floating population” — the boat people who spend their entire lives on the junks in the harbor, some proudly claiming never to have set foot on land (except for funerals, which don’t count).

The peninsula opposite the east coast of Ap Lei Chau island contains Ocean Park (open daily 10am–6pm; admission HK$150 adults, HK$75 children), which has become one of Hong Kong’s biggest attractions.
Linking the lowland and highland sections of the park, a cable-car system offers spectacular views across to the islands of the South China Sea.
Stanley was once one of the main fishing villages on Hong Kong Island.
Though much smaller than Hong Kong Island, Kowloon has almost twice the population.
The waterfront here offers unparalled views of the harbor and Hong Kong Island.
The boats go on to the friendly fishermen’s island of Tap Mun, in Mirs Bay, with stops in remote hamlets of the Sai Kung Peninsula.
Excursion companies sell a variety of orientation cruises of Hong Kong harbor that include a look at some of its 235 outlying islands.
Excursion companies sell a variety of orientation cruises of Hong Kong harbor that include a look at some of its 235 outlying islands.

From the ferry terminals on Hong Kong Island you can escape to islands without cars or cares, where the local people smile “hello” and, if you’re lucky, point you to a secret beach for the ultimate in quality leisure time.

From the ferry terminals on Hong Kong Island you can escape to islands without cars or cares, where the local people smile “hello” and, if you’re lucky, point you to a secret beach for the ultimate in quality leisure time.
The mountainous island of Lantau is the biggest in the colony, and covers nearly twice the area of Hong Kong Island.
The mountainous island of Lantau is the biggest in the colony, and covers nearly twice the area of Hong Kong Island.
The mountainous island of Lantau is the biggest in the colony, and covers nearly twice the area of Hong Kong Island.
More than half the island is parkland, and there is a 70-km (45-mile) circular hiking trail (see page 92).
Ferries depart from Central every two hours between 6:10am and 10:30pm to Silvermine Bay (Mui Wo), where a bus terminal has buses to all parts of the island.
The most famous site on the island is the world’s tallest seated bronze statue of Buddha at 22 m (72.
The island’s largest community is Tai O. The people of this picturesque village make their living by fishing, duck-breeding, and food-processing.
Some 10 km (6 miles) west of Hong Kong lies this small, crowded island, only one square mile in size.
The island has a checkered past of smuggling and pira cy.
That era is gone now, but other elements of the island’s old life are preserved.
But the most interesting thing to do here is to explore the two villages on the island, Cheung Chau and San Wai.
Only 35 minutes by ferry from Central, Lamma Island is perfect for swimming, hiking, picnicking, birdwatching, or just sitting back to watch the bananas grow.
Only 35 minutes by ferry from Central, Lamma Island is perfect for swimming, hiking, picnicking, birdwatching, or just sitting back to watch the bananas grow.
Hong Kong’s third largest island has a population of only about 12,000; it is still largely undeveloped, and life on Lamma, if not totally primitive, is close to the essentials.
Archaeologists indicate that Lamma has probably been inhabited for some 4,000 years, and the island is known as “Hong Kong’s Stone Age Island. ”
Archaeologists indicate that Lamma has probably been inhabited for some 4,000 years, and the island is known as “Hong Kong’s Stone Age Island. ”

Among other legends surrounding the statue is a very modern one: During the Chinese Cultural Revolution, when Red Guards were running rampant on Wanchai island, just a swim away, the image of St. James is said to have stepped down from the altar and halted an invasion.
Bridges link Macau with its two islands.
The island is also the designated home of the University of East Asia.
The waterfront drive parallels the shore of a Chinese island, and boats headed to China pass through the narrow waterway.
Seac Pai Van Park, on the west coast of the island is an interesting natural preserve with aNatural History Museum.
The atmosphere of 19th-century Canton is best evoked on Shamian Island, a haunting, nostalgic place in the Pearl River.
This small formerly residential island, beautifully shaded by banyan trees, was the home of the closed community of the foreign colony in the era of “concessions. ”
The island also has Guangzhou’s first modern luxury resort hotel.
